Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: Children are about to finish school, and the parent should pick them up
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: The snow was coming down harder than I’d seen all winter, swirling around the taxi as I inched along the highway. My passenger, a nervous businessman, kept glancing at his watch and muttering about missing his flight. I could feel his anxiety pressing on me, the unspoken expectation that I’d somehow get him to the airport on time, no matter the weather. My phone buzzed on the dashboard—an alert from the school. Dismissal was early because of the storm. My kids would be waiting, bundled up and shivering, expecting me to be there like I always promised. I pictured their faces, scanning the line of cars, hoping to see me. But the airport was still miles away, and traffic was crawling. My hands tightened on the wheel. I was supposed to be reliable, both as a parent and as a driver. But right now, I couldn’t see how I could possibly be both. The weight of their expectations pressed down on me, and I felt torn in two, the storm outside nothing compared to the one inside my chest.
